5.speaker: Gale
5.text: We really ought to go speak to Elminster. If not out of curiosity, then at least to make sure he doesn't eat his way through all of our supplies.

6.speaker: Gale
6.text: My condition is worsening again. I need to consume some powerful magic, or it may become volatile.

150.speaker: Gale
150.text: I know we have other things on our mind, but please - do not neglect my request. It is most, most urgent.

239.speaker: Gale
239.text: It's Astarion, isn't it? I've felt the tension between you. I told myself it was casual, not a matter of the heart... but clearly I was wrong.

98.speaker: Gale
98.text: You two have grown closer than I thought possible. And it looks like I'm the last to know.

140.speaker: Gale
140.text: I... I thought you would show me the respect of telling me first, but no matter. You can tell me now - who is it to be? Me, or him?

164.speaker: Player
164.text: I want to be with Astarion, I'm sorry.

241.speaker: Gale
241.text: I see. Well, I suppose he does have a certain charm about him. If you're into that sort of thing.

21.speaker: Gale
21.text: I'll just put my feelings to one side. I think that's best for everyone. It's certainly the best thing for me.

25.speaker: Gale
25.text: I won't leave - not unless you want me to, or until fate forces my hand. If your friendship is all we have, then I will be happy to have it. Eventually.
25.context: NodeContext: Very gracious, declaring an intent to move on (even if it's painful right now). 'Eventually' not snarky - just acknowledging it will take time to be happy with only friendship

329.speaker: Player
329.text: For what it's worth, I'm sorry.

280.speaker: Gale
280.text: Worry not. I carry my regrets wherever I go, and am used to their weight. One more will not break my back.
280.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

306.speaker: Player
306.text: I'm glad to have you around, Gale.

137.speaker: Gale
137.text: And I am lucky to have met you... my friend.
137.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

155.speaker: Gale
155.text: I could no more hate you than I could go without air.
155.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

307.speaker: Player
307.text: I want to be with you and Astarion, equally. Why limit ourselves?

166.speaker: Gale
166.text: I'm sorry, but to know I had less than the whole of your heart - I can't do it. Not when I would give all of myself to you.

149.speaker: Gale
149.text: Call me greedy, stubborn, old-fashioned... but I cannot change who I am, or how I love.

328.speaker: Gale
328.text: In any case, know that I harbour no ill-will. I would rather see you happy with another, than not happy at all.

260.speaker: Player
260.text: I didn't know you felt so strongly, Gale.

283.speaker: Gale
283.text: Perhaps I should have done more. Been more charming, more flattering, harder to reach... but I was only myself, and sometimes that isn't enough.

85.speaker: Gale
85.text: Whatever your decision, I will accept it. But you must choose. You cannot have us both.

66.speaker: Gale
66.text: You would sacrifice what you have with Lae'zel, for me? She will not be pleased...
66.context: NodeContext: Slightly nervous at the thought of an angry Lae'zel bearing down on him

134.speaker: Player
134.text: She's intense, but not unreasonable. She'll get over it.

153.speaker: Gale
153.text: I think you're right. Not one to let emotions get in the way, I'd say.

158.speaker: Player
158.text: A very good point. I'll make sure she's unarmed when I tell her.

124.speaker: Gale
124.text: I'm sure it would never come to that. A clip round the ear perhaps, but nothing you can't handle.

170.speaker: Player
170.text: You're right. I can't let her down. I'm sorry Gale - I choose her.

79.speaker: Gale
79.text: And what of Karlach? Her heart can surely break, though it burns.

55.speaker: Player
55.text: She's intense, but not unreasonable. She'll get over it.

11.speaker: Player
11.text: A very good point. I'll make sure she's unarmed when I tell her.

263.speaker: Gale
263.text: But what of Wyll? He's a born romantic, just as I am. To lose you could kill him...

83.speaker: Player
83.text: A true romantic wouldn't stand in the way of another's happiness. He'll accept it.

299.speaker: Gale
299.text: You're right. And broken hearts mend, in time. I'm living proof of that.

16.speaker: Player
16.text: If he threatens anything so dramatic, I'll kill him myself.

100.speaker: Gale
100.text: I'm sure he'll take it with grace. Or at least pretend to.

231.speaker: Gale
231.text: And what of Astarion? I fear you are one of the things that keeps his darkest impulses at bay.

145.speaker: Player
145.text: Then he needs to manage that for himself. I'm not his keeper.

13.speaker: Gale
13.text: You are right. And your heart should not be the price of his redemption. He must earn that for himself.

184.speaker: Gale
184.text: I am beyond lucky to have you. Sometimes even the power of the Weave seems mundane, compared to how you make me feel.

61.speaker: Player
61.text: He will still have my support. But as a friend, nothing more.

182.speaker: Gale
182.text: And he will be grateful for it. I'm sure. Your friendship is a blessing for anyone, though I'm glad our bond is becoming something more.

128.speaker: Player
128.text: I can't. I'm sorry Gale... you and I are no more.

334.speaker: Gale
334.text: Don't apologise. You must not deny your heart's desire. I would not want you to.

240.speaker: Gale
240.text: And what of Shadowheart? It took a lot for her to open her heart to you. She'll not exactly be pleased if you decide to break it for her...

88.speaker: Player
88.text: She's intense, but not unreasonable. She'll get over it.

17.speaker: Player
17.text: I will always treasure my bond with her. But as a friend.

138.speaker: Gale
138.text: And she will be grateful for it. I'm sure. Your friendship is a blessing for anyone, though I'm glad our bond is becoming something more.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: You're right, it's for the best we aren't involved. I'm sorry.

92.speaker: Gale
92.text: Ooft, you are a very Cone of Cold!
92.context: NodeContext: Wounded/indignant. Player broke up with him then just strolled off.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: Then I choose you. Astarion was a bit of fun, nothing more.

20.speaker: Gale
20.text: Ahem. I hope you're not here to ask about our recent, erm, activities. I'd rather those were consigned to the footnotes of our romance, if it's all the same with you.
20.context: NodeContext: Clears throat awkwardly at the start. The first time you've spoken since having a threesome

80.speaker: Gale
80.text: I'd normally be buoyed by the sight of so many friendly faces. I fear they'd be far less welcoming if they know of my condition.
80.context: NodeContext: Worried - the orb is destabilised

211.speaker: Gale
211.text: My need is more urgent than ever - I must consume an item soon. I cannot stay in the company of good people otherwise. Too risky.
211.context: NodeContext: Worried - the orb is destabilised

248.speaker: Gale
248.text: We must find a suitable artefact urgently.

52.speaker: Gale
52.text: My need is more urgent than ever - I must consume an item soon. We have exactly what I need in our possession - please, just give it to me.

218.speaker: Gale
218.text: Karlach, yes? You burn for each other in more ways than one.

76.speaker: Gale
76.text: I... I thought you would show me the respect of telling me first, but no matter. You can tell me now - who is it to be? Me, or her?

333.speaker: Player
333.text: I'm sorry, Gale. I want to be with Karlach.

175.speaker: Gale
175.text: Don't be - she has a good heart. Poor phrasing - she has a terrible heart. But she's surprisingly caring, considering it.

289.speaker: Player
289.text: Love doesn't have to follow such strict lines, Gale. I have room for you in my heart as well.

168.speaker: Gale
168.text: I finally have the tome I needed. Such knowledge - such power - contained in such a small object.

243.speaker: Gale
243.text: I don't wish to nag, but have you put any thought towards what I asked of you? I must consume the magic from a suitable vessel soon.

3.speaker: Gale
3.text: We've already found something of sufficient potency. Please - give it to me.

323.speaker: Gale
323.text: My condition is not overly fussy. So long as there is sufficient power in the item, it will be satisfied.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: Don't worry. I'm going to find something.

310.speaker: Gale
310.text: You have my thanks, though unless we find a treatment soon, you won't have my full strength.

31.speaker: Gale
31.text: If I cannot remain stable... well, let's hope it doesn't come to that. I'd hate to cut our acquaintance short, shall we say?

118.speaker: Gale
118.text: Do you need anything else of me?

42.speaker: Player
42.text: Honestly, it's not my priority right now.

143.speaker: Gale
143.text: I'm afraid it remains mine. But there is still time yet. Just remember what I ask - it's a small price, for what I hope I bring to our company.

48.speaker: Gale
48.text: I'd sooner we set our course together than deprive you of my company sooner than the fates might otherwise have decreed. It's really up to you.

129.speaker: Gale
129.text: My condition likes being ignored as little as I do. I must consume another artefact. And soon.

172.speaker: Gale
172.text: The Annals of Karsus... The preamble to a civilisation's downfall, committed to parchment by the very hand that wrought its destruction.

320.speaker: Gale
320.text: If the crown atop the elder brain was truly forged by Karsus himself, this book will confirm it. All we have to do is turn the page...
320.context: NodeContext: Excited, a glint in his eye

135.speaker: Gale
135.text: The truth of the crown, I hope. All that stands between us and enlightenment is the turn of a page...
135.context: NodeContext: Excited, a glint in his eye

162.speaker: Gale
162.text: If my suspicions are correct, the crown currently perched atop the elder brain may be one of Karsus' design. And now we hold the very tome that could confirm it.
162.context: NodeContext: Excited, a glint in his eye

130.speaker: Player
130.text: Don't stand on ceremony - see what it says.

331.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes book out (of his own inventory),

99.context: CinematicNodeContext: Player hands book to Gale

254.speaker: Gale
254.text: That devil Raphael was telling the truth. There's no doubt - the Crown of Karsus is what's controlling the elder brain.

203.speaker: Gale
203.text: This isn't what I expected... this is much more. The Crown of Karsus.

277.speaker: Gale
277.text: And this - this is no mere journal - it contains Karsus' original plans for the Crown's construction. His designs for godhood.
277.context: NodeContext: Gale looking down at the book, reading. Excited, cogs starting to whirr in his mind...

38.speaker: Player
38.text: The design for self-destruction, more like. Didn't this crown kill Karsus?

338.speaker: Gale
338.text: Not exactly. It was what he did with it that sealed his fate, and for a time, that of magic itself. The Crown was merely the means.

10.speaker: Player
10.text: Godhood? I know crowns are an ego boost, but that's ridiculous.

282.speaker: Gale
282.text: Gods have ascended through far stranger means - a circle drawn on a globe, a walk in a swamp, the destruction of a magical stone. Why not with a symbol of such innate authority?
282.context: InternalNodeContext: Diancastra, Wastri, Finder WyvernspurNodeContext: Doesnt' really want to waste time justifying this to you

202.speaker: Gale
202.text: Not from scratch - unless you happen to have several pounds of the purest Netherese metals in that pack of yours?

259.speaker: Gale
259.text: Don't worry - I'm not asking you to surrender anything else on my account. What's called for here is something altogether different.

316.speaker: Player
316.text: How did such a powerful object end up in the hands of the Absolute?

36.speaker: Gale
36.text: I haven't the foggiest. No doubt through some nefarious means - the crown's existence had been consigned to legend centuries ago.

177.speaker: Gale
177.text: The book states that the Crown and Netherstones were originally one construct, seemingly sundered at the moment of Karsus' downfall.

302.speaker: Gale
302.text: If we can collect the crown's setting, and the three Netherstones, and with the correct invocation of certain spells and gestures detailed in these notes... I think I could reforge it.
302.context: NodeContext: Running through the instructions out loud, confirming this for himself as much s the player

117.speaker: Player
117.text: Aren't you forgetting something? We have to hand the Crown to Raphael...

50.speaker: Gale
50.text: A situation I suggest we remedy with the utmost urgency.

179.speaker: Gale
179.text: I promise you - the power such an item would give us is worth transcending all nine Hells for. The heavens too, while we're at it.
179.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale puts book away (generic)NodeContext: Gleam in his eyes, excitement

339.speaker: Gale
339.text: To every end you can imagine, and a thousand more beyond.

121.speaker: Player
121.text: We already know the crown's dangerous. Wouldn't that make things worse?

119.speaker: Gale
119.text: Worse? It could be the best thing that ever happened to me. To us.

77.speaker: Gale
77.text: Just think of it... the power of the gods in mortal hands at last. We'd be free of doctrine and dogma, confined only by the limits of our imaginations.

123.speaker: Gale
123.text: We must discuss this further - but quietly. Privately.

108.speaker: Gale
108.text: Find me later, and I will show you something truly divine. I will show you what a crown like this could mean for both of us.

204.speaker: Player
204.text: Can't you just tell me now?

122.speaker: Gale
122.text: Afraid not. What I have to show you requires us to be its only witness, and our minds to share in the most exquisite concentration.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: That crown is an abomination, Gale. I don't need a private conversation to understand that.

43.speaker: Gale
43.text: Please - don't be too hasty about this. It would be a pity to reach that conclusion without a true understanding of what this could mean for us.

249.speaker: Gale
249.text: Don't worry - your patience will be amply rewarded.

235.speaker: Gale
235.text: I promise you - the gods will never grant us such a blessing, no matter how much we worship and adore them.

264.speaker: Player
264.text: You dismiss the entire pantheon so easily. Not all gods are selfish.

327.speaker: Gale
327.text: Some gods may delude themselves into believing they care about their worshippers, but when it comes down to it - we're all expendable. Children to be appeased, not respected.

112.speaker: Gale
112.text: I worshipped Mystra loyally for years, and in that time she granted me the barest sliver of the power I was ready to wield.

58.speaker: Gale
58.text: Even with the fate of the world at stake, she had little more to offer me than the means of blowing myself up at a more convenient time. She's done nothing to help us.

261.speaker: Gale
261.text: Mystra wanted the brain obliterated because of this crown. She fears a world in which such power is beyond her control - ready to be claimed by Karsus' successor.

15.speaker: Player
15.text: I thought you were past this kind of temptation, Gale. You know exactly where such over-reaching leads.

208.speaker: Gale
208.text: Neither of us can know what truly may be if we don't at least try. Potential is nothing in itself - just a fleeting dream, unless we drag it into the waking world. Please, at least think on it.

223.speaker: Gale
223.text: Powerful as he was, Karsus lacked some advantages I can lay claim to.

14.speaker: Gale
14.text: I know Mystra - intimately. And I carry a fragment of the Weave itself within my body. Karsus achieved many things, but he never managed that.

39.speaker: Gale
39.text: A long road lies ahead before the Crown comes into our possession. All I ask for now is that you not dismiss this possibility out of hand. Please - at least think on it.

127.speaker: Player
127.text: Gale - I'm urging you to drop this. This Crown cannot be reforged.

337.speaker: Gale
337.text: I see. I suppose I am asking you to take a leap of faith even the most loyal of companions might struggle to land gracefully.

72.speaker: Gale
72.text: I've spent so long feeling... inferior, shut out from my destiny over such a simple act of youthful enthusiasm.

86.speaker: Gale
86.text: Perhaps I got carried away with the thought this Crown could give me back what Mystra took. Cure me, even.

258.speaker: Player
258.text: You're still destined for greatness, Gale. But you won't find it chasing Karsus' shadow.

222.speaker: Gale
222.text: You're right. There aren't many wizards who'd care to be mentioned in the same breath as him, or his folly.

300.speaker: Player
300.text: Don't give up yet. There will be an answer - it just isn't the Crown.

125.speaker: Gale
125.text: Very well then - I will try my utmost to share in your optimism. Nothing wrong with a little hope, after all.

295.speaker: Player
295.text: You're deluded, Gale. The crown is clearly dangerous, as is pursuing it.

281.speaker: Gale
281.text: Of course it's dangerous - but that's hardly a unique quality when it comes to the purposes we've pursued together.
281.context: NodeContext: A bit snippy - doesn't appreciate hearing this

59.speaker: Gale
59.text: Regardless - you've made your point. I shall put thoughts of the crown aside for the time being.

141.speaker: Gale
141.text: It gives me some courage, to think that you see greatness in me. I hope I live up to your expectations.

250.speaker: Gale
250.text: Whatever comes of this, we cannot allow the Crown to be reforged in Raphael's image.

286.speaker: Gale
286.text: A devil wielding the might of Karsus... it would be the end of everything.
286.context: NodeContext: Stern, almost horrified at the thought

44.speaker: Gale
44.text: At least we can face our enemy armed with the knowledge of its true nature. And of the stakes, should we fail to defeat it.

311.speaker: Gale
311.text: Thank you for letting me read this. At least we can face our enemy armed with the knowledge of its true nature. And of the stakes, should we fail to defeat it.
311.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale takes out and hands the book to the player below frame.

226.speaker: Player
226.text: I promise to think about it, then. That's all I can offer.

169.speaker: Player
169.text: Wallowing in the dirt? Is that what our time together has meant to you?

305.speaker: Gale
305.text: I didn't mean that as a slight. I cherish our adventures, but even if we prevail, you must know the end is in sight, mustn't you?

219.speaker: Player
219.text: Seems like you've got this all figured out. I won't stand in your way.

91.speaker: Gale
91.text: This is no passing whim, trust me. If I can obtain that crown, it will affect us all. It is not a decision I'll take lightly.

160.speaker: Gale
160.text: It's our future that I'm thinking of - we can't rely on anyone else to do it for us.

33.speaker: Gale
33.text: For now - we've learned all we can.

27.speaker: Gale
27.text: Whatever comes of this, we cannot allow the Crown to be reforged in Raphael's image.

146.speaker: Gale
146.text: A devil wielding the might of Karsus... it would be the end of everything.
146.context: NodeContext: Stern, almost horrified at the thought

270.speaker: Gale
270.text: That tome proved to be even more valuable than I ever could have imagined. For both of us.

63.speaker: Gale
63.text: Here's your tome back. It proved to be even more valuable than I ever could have imagined. For both of us.
63.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale returns the book to the player below frame.

233.speaker: Player
233.text: You're a convincing man, Gale. The crown sounds promising.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: What you're suggesting is blasphemy. You'd be wise to banish these notions from your head.

188.speaker: Player
188.text: Mystra is no friend of the Dark Lady. If you can dethrone her, you have my support.

103.speaker: Player
103.text: The pursuit of knowledge and power is in our nature. There's no question - you must do this.

115.speaker: Gale
115.text: I'm glad you can recognise this for the opportunity it is. Nevertheless, it is not a step to take lightly.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: Or to destroy the next wizard who attempts it. The attempt would kill you as it killed Karsus.

290.speaker: Gale
290.text: Do you think I had not considered that? I have no intention of repeating his folly.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: And you believe yourself to be that successor?

216.speaker: Gale
216.text: Not until this moment, but I can't help beginning to see such a destiny unfold before me.

269.speaker: Player
269.text: This is no ordinary artefact, Gale. Do this and you'd challenge the gods themselves.

326.speaker: Gale
326.text: Perhaps they deserve to be challenged. Perhaps you and I deserve better than to live and die as their pawns.

287.speaker: Player
287.text: So you want the Crown to settle a score with Mystra?

22.speaker: Gale
22.text: Ambition is not a sin. To question the powers that rule us is not treason. We must at least try - why wallow in the dirt when we can reach for the stars?

332.speaker: Player
332.text: And you think Mystra will let you do this?

298.speaker: Gale
298.text: I don't know. Ao does not look kindly on gods meddling in mortal affairs - she may have no choice but to stand by and let events unfold.

57.speaker: Player
57.text: Mortals are far better guardians of their fates than the gods. We have more to lose.

12.speaker: Gale
12.text: Then you're already wiser than me. That's a lesson I've only recently learned.

297.speaker: Player
297.text: Don't dare to assume why I worship. Not all of us share such transactional relationships with our gods.

180.speaker: Gale
180.text: But do you not expect something in return for your devotion? Some favour, some stir of courage, some response?

271.speaker: Player
271.text: You 'think'? What happens if you fail?

313.speaker: Gale
313.text: Well, there'd be risk in such an endeavour, but only proportionate to the reward.
313.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale puts book away (generic)NodeContext: Doesn't want to get bogged down by doubts like these

151.speaker: Player
151.text: That Crown's caused chaos. We should be seeking a way to destroy it, not make it more powerful.

238.speaker: Gale
238.text: Do not mistake the crown itself for the actions of its wearer, or rather, those controlling its wearer at present.

308.speaker: Gale
308.text: If we could restore its former glory, it would no longer be a mere leash and collar, used to subjugate friend or foe. It would be something greater. Something divine.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: Karsus? Crown? You might need to catch me up a bit...

274.speaker: Gale
274.text: Karsus - I believe I mentioned him before. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself.

7.speaker: Gale
7.text: Karsus. The child-who-would-become-a-god. He was the most powerful wizard ever known... and he attempted to unseat the goddess of magic herself.

97.speaker: Gale
97.text: Only she used the last of her power to block him from the Weave. His magic faltered. The great flying cities of Netheril plunged from the sky. Karsus' Folly.

221.speaker: Gale
221.text: That goddess of magic was reborn as Mystra. She ruled on, while Netherese magic was reduced to mere fragments of what Karsus once wielded - artefacts, the most powerful of which appears to be his Crown.

104.speaker: Player
104.text: I'm not sure I want you delving into this.

154.speaker: Gale
154.text: And since when have we sought to avoid trouble, eh? Come now, the knowledge lurking between those pages could help us greatly. Don't be a hindrance after being such a great help.
154.context: NodeContext: Keeping composure, but annoyed the player is denying him.

136.speaker: Player
136.text: We don't have time for this. Forget about the book.

87.speaker: Gale
87.text: Then we ought to make time. This could be the answer to everything.

23.speaker: Player
23.text: Fine - take it. Do  what you must.

173.speaker: Player
173.text: It's just a book. Now let's speak no more of this.

190.speaker: Gale
190.text: I hope you're right, because if you're wrong, there's no words to describe the opportunity you'll have squandered.

193.speaker: Gale
193.text: Your cheeks are flush, there's a twinkle in your eye... but I think I am no longer the cause.
193.context: InternalNodeContext: Player did act 1 romance scene with Gale, but not act 2 yet. Player did act 2 romanec scene with another character.

206.speaker: Gale
206.text: It seems you've found your heart's desire, but with someone else. And who would I be, to stand in the way of such a union?

187.speaker: Gale
187.text: I assume you didn't come here to seek my blessing, though. Was there something else you needed?

265.speaker: Gale
265.text: Lae'zel. I could scarcely believe it at first, but I've seen the glances you share, the way you lean into each other's whispers. There is something between you two.

262.speaker: Gale
262.text: To seek the heart of a githyanki warrior takes a good deal of courage. I can only think what you share must be quite serious, to brave such a task.

174.speaker: Player
174.text: I want to be with Lae'zel, I'm sorry.

278.speaker: Gale
278.text: If that is what will make you happy... well, I am not the one who would stand in your way.

68.speaker: Player
68.text: Just because I share something with Lae'zel doesn't mean you and I need drift apart...

56.speaker: Gale
56.text: We'll have to disagree on that score - competing against a githyanki warrior would be very poor for my health.
56.context: NodeContext: Sad, but with a bleak chuckle

200.speaker: Gale
200.text: Don't worry, I know Minthara insisted on you abandoning me. Or at least I assume I'm 'the wizard' she was referring to.
200.context: InternalNodeContext: Pre-partnered with companion, partnered with Gale.

317.speaker: Gale
317.text: I'm happy to stay as your friend, for as long as you'll have me. Though I'll keep a safe distance from your new lover, if that's all the same to you. Now, did you seek me out for a reason?

26.speaker: Gale
26.text: Whatever lurks in the darkness ahead, I can hardly face it in my present condition. I need my full strength to stand against such shadows.

293.speaker: Gale
293.text: We've already found enough magic to soothe its disquiet, if you'll just give me what I need.

229.speaker: Gale
229.text: I trust you'll treat the matter with the appropriate exigency. The moment we find a suitable item, please - give it to me.

189.speaker: Gale
189.text: I cannot keep throwing myself headlong into such danger while I am so unstable. If it my condition is not treated soon, I will be compelled to leave.

279.speaker: Gale
279.text: I'm afraid this is where we part ways - my condition's deteriorated beyond even my capacity to salvage.
279.context: NodeContext: Forced cheeriness, he's going off into the wilderness to die

322.speaker: Gale
322.text: It would be selfish of me to stay, when in doing so I'd be putting you, and everyone else within spitting distance in catastrophic peril.
322.context: NodeContext: Saddened - he's about to wander off into the wilderness to die, essentially

191.speaker: Player
191.text: Please don't leave me, Gale. I love you.

291.speaker: Player
291.text: You can't leave. We've only just begun to grow closer...

183.speaker: Player
183.text: A noble decision. You're a good man, Gale.

276.speaker: Gale
276.text: Oh, I wouldn't say that. Just a man who's been living with the consequences of his actions for a tad too long.
276.context: NodeContext: Forced cheeriness, he's going off into the wilderness to die

325.speaker: Gale
325.text: If you recall nothing else of my time with you, let it be this: you were most special to me. And it will be your face I picture, when the end comes.
325.context: NodeContext: Earnest, sorrowful. He'll leave the party for good immediately after this line

113.speaker: Gale
113.text: A shame. This is a journey I'd have liked to see through to the end, but I've my own finale to face. And it's best I face it alone.
113.context: NodeContext: Sad resignation, but getting on with it. Going off into the wilderness to die

110.speaker: Player
110.text: Wait. I can still give you the artefacts you need.

205.speaker: Gale
205.text: It's too late for that, I'm afraid. My condition has shifted somehow - its hunger for the Weave can no longer be satisfied.

319.speaker: Player
319.text: Make sure you're nice and far away before you keel over, won't you?

242.speaker: Gale
242.context: NodeContext: Not impressed - he's trying to say goodbye before he dies, and the player's taking the piss

285.speaker: Gale
285.text: Ah, I'm glad you've a moment for me.

251.speaker: Gale
251.text: My predicament has become rather urgent. I need a magical artefact to consume, right now.

107.speaker: Gale
107.text: It is Wyll, yes? The connection is palpable - no tadpole required.

340.speaker: Gale
340.text: He is a good man - I will not hesitate to say so. But I had hoped I was a good man also. And a worthy one.

111.speaker: Player
111.text: I want to be with Wyll, I'm sorry.

273.speaker: Gale
273.text: Not for me to stand in your way, then. You two will make a fine couple... I can picture it already.

253.speaker: Player
253.text: I share something special with Wyll - but with you also. That needn't change.

247.speaker: Gale
247.text: I'm not sure Wyll's family would appreciate their heir apparent being forced to share.

159.speaker: Gale
159.text: It's Shadowheart, isn't it? For one who guards her secrets so closely, she's made no attempt at hiding how much she wants you.

1.speaker: Player
1.text: I want to be with Shadowheart, I'm sorry.

266.speaker: Player
266.text: My heart has room for both of you, if you're willing to share?

93.speaker: Gale
93.text: Shadowheart doesn't seem the type to share her toys, never mind her lovers. Neither am I.
